title: Chelsea are playing as well as anyone under Frank Lampard, says Paul Merson
text:
Frank Lampard has led Chelsea on a seven-game winning run (Picture: Getty)

Paul Merson has praised Frank Lampard for transforming Chelsea into one of the best footballing sides in the Premier League this season while aiming a dig at his predecessor Maurizio Sarri’s ‘dire’ tactical philosophy.

Lampard has earned plaudits for implementing a more attractive style of play this season and his methods are clearly working well with Chelsea’s 4-2 success over Burnley on Saturday marking seven successive victories.

Although Sarri enjoyed a productive single campaign at Stamford Bridge by winning the Europa League and securing a third-place finish in the Premier League, the Italian’s ‘Sarri-ball’ tactics were far from popular.

As well as ushering in a different way of playing, Merson also believes that Lampard has created a better all-round team as they are longer reliant on one player, as was often the case last season with Eden Hazard.

Christian Pulisic was the star of the show during Chelsea’s 4-2 thrashing of Burnley on Saturday (Picture: Getty)

‘I think Frank Lampard has been outstanding – they’re playing football as good as anyone,’ Merson told Sky Sports. ‘When I watched Chelsea last year, it was dire in a way. I know they won the Europa League final, should have beaten Man City in the Carabao Cup final, and they came third in the Premier League, but the football wasn’t great.

‘Now, the football is fantastic and everybody is joining in. Last season, you gave the ball to Eden Hazard, hope he did something and if he had an off day, Chelsea had no chance. Now, everybody is chipping in and they’re all kids, enthusiastic and putting in performances.’

Christian Pulisic was Chelsea’s star at Turf Moor as he netted a hat-trick on his first Premier League start since August and his performance is symbolic of Chelsea’s season so far with a number of young players catching the eye.

Academy graduates Tammy Abraham, Mason Mount, Fikayo Tomori and Callum Hudson-Odoi have all emerged as integral members of Lampard’s first-team squad and Merson thinks another manager might not have utilised their talents.

He added: ‘The future is bright for Chelsea, although they have fallen over it. It was put on them and I don’t know that without the transfer embargo or Frank Lampard, how many of them would be in the team. I think half of this team that are ripping it up now would be out on loan in the Championship.

‘And you’ve got to give Frank credit. He could have easily played safe and looked after himself, a lot of managers do and he could have gone with the experience, but he hasn’t. He’s thought of the club more than himself and it’s paid dividends.’
